SEMBAWANG SEASIDE PARK
(Commencement of work)


    1. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Law and National Development when work will start on the proposed seaside park in the Sembawang Constituency.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Port of Singapore Authority has earmarked the Sembawang seaside park for expansion of the Sembawang port. My Ministry is discussing this proposal with the PSA. If agreement is reached

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1973 TO 31ST MARCH, 1974

2.32 p.m.

    Head 0801 --

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0801 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*. (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Ho Kah Leong.).

    In the kampung areas there still exist common problems which have to take a considerably long time to solve and

Column: 737

with much effort. Therefore, in the present circumstances, I find it necessary to speak up in this House with all earnestness to appeal on behalf of the rural people, hoping that the authorities can sympathise with the difficulties and sufferings of these people and to exercise some flexibility in order to allow them to enjoy a more reasonable and better livelihood and a more hygienic way of living. In this way, I hope it can reduce the loss to the country. By loss, I mean the problem of the drinking water of the poor rural people.

    We all know that in this world if there is no water, it is tantamount to having no blood in our human body. We know that water is precious, especially in Singapore as it has to depend on a neighbouring country for its water supply. Therefore, water is all the more precious to us. In recent months, we use to hear or see on the television, over the radio and Rediffusion, in public places and in the newspapers, the appeal and advice not to waste water. In fact, even if water is inexhaustible, because it is a primary need for life, we have to treasure it. We should not waste it.

    In the rural areas, there are still some people staying in attap and wooden houses. Originally they had to depend on public standpipes for their drinking water. However, since many public standpipes have been shut or removed, their water supply was also cut off. But for the sake of making a living and because of health, they are willing to save up to pay for the cost of installation of water pipes. However, their applications were turned down because they have no house numbers. Thus they could not get any water supply. As a result, these people have no alternative but to try to get their water supply from their nearest friends or some good samaritans. Even the Minister can appreciate that they cannot live without water. So this puts them in a predicament. They can only get very little water for their daily needs. They pass their days in this way, as though they are living in hell!

Column: 738



    In the rural areas water is very important because many of them rear domestic livestock and poultry. Poultry animals are not like human beings. They will defecate anywhere and at any time they like. They cannot be taught to go to proper places to do so. In these circumstances how are we going to prevent pollution of the environment?

    Now our Government has set up a department for the control of environmental pollution. Since some of our people live in such unhygienic environment, how are we going to bring up a new rugged generation? If this situation were to persist for some time, I am sure this will become a burden to the society, and it will also constitute a loss to the country.

    I believe that Members will also agree with me that in the rural areas, even today there are still many unauthorised attap houses. This is a fact. This is not something that only happens today. You can trace this fact up to the time when Rallies founded Singapore and set up the colonial Government. However, since rural people are in existence, if we do not supply water to them, we can all feel that these unfortunate people who stay in houses without numbers will not be able to live in a hygienic environment. Of course, I do not mean to say that the Government has not done anything. Ever since the present Government came to office, it has done many things. However, we should also remember that in the present circumstances we can still try to solve the problem, if not, the fundamental cause of the ills. The Government can exercise some flexibility and relax its rules and so allow those people who stay in unnumbered houses to install water-pipes in order to solve their problem of drinking water. In this way, the Government is keeping to its policy of giving the people a better environment to live in. This will also promote public health and prevent pollution from worsening. Furthermore,

Column: 739

if the Government insists on its hard and fast rule that houses without numbers should not be allowed to install piped water, then our recent efforts in the various campaigns in respect of anti-mosquito, anti-pollution, etc, will be wasted.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, as a Member of Parliament from a rural constituency, I fully endorse and sympathise with the Member for Paya Lebar in respect of the hardships suffered by the rural people of Singapore. It is, therefore, my hope that the Minister will give sympathetic consideration to his appeal.

    Here I would like to take the opportunity to raise a few points with the Minister. The first question is that of the disposal of industrial waste. We know that industrial development in Singapore is in full swing and is going at a very high rate. As a result there has also been an increase of industrial waste in Singapore. In my view, the present method of disposal of industrial waste is inadequate. Whether it is in respect of a single-storey factory or flatted factories, we can see that around such factories there is always a collection of industrial waste, heaps and heaps of rubbish attracting a lot of flies and other pests. They are also a fire hazard. In fact, some factories have suffered losses as a result of fire. I wonder whether the Minister concerned has any new method of disposal of the accumulating industrial waste in Singapore.

    The next question I wish to raise is in connection with air pollution in Jurong Town. Jurong Town has developed into an industrial area with many factories in production. There are some 40,000 people living in the residential part of the industrial town.

2.45 p.m.

    According to a recent survey, there is indication to show that the air in Jurong Town is the most polluted. As

Column: 740

a result, there have been many complaints from residents who are concerned over the increasing pollution of the air in their environment. I would, therefore, ask the Minister whether he is aware of the increase of air pollution in Jurong Town. I have received complaints from residents in Jurong Town that every morning when they wake up they can see and feel a layer of black dust on their furniture, or on any flat surface in the house. I would like to ask the Minister whether the black dust is injurious to health and whether steps are taken to ensure that the production of such black dust is minimised.

    Lastly, Sir, I would like to raise the question regarding the hygienic conditions of Jurong Town. Jurong Town is a model industrial town in Singapore. Tourists very often pay visits to this industrial town. Because of these foreign visits, whether the state of the environment is hygienic or not will leave a good or bad impression on the foreign visitors. Sir, does the Minister know what is the actual position regarding the hygienic environment of Jurong Town? I have seen that in some places the situation is far from satisfactory. Some drains are choked up in one place, and in other places, rubbish is strewn all over. These are the places occupied by foreign workers. Perhaps these imported labourers do not know the legal aspects of our social requirements. There may be cases of those who choose to ignore our requirements. But the fact remains that there are people in Jurong Town who do not keep to public health standards. I wonder whether the Minister concerned can do something about this.

    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am most happy to learn that the Member for Paya Lebar is now well aware that water is precious. He has further emphasised how precious water is to us in Singapore by enumerating the difficulties which some of his constituents have faced because they suddenly found themselves without water. I think, having understood how

Column: 741

precious water is, he will probably understand the reason why we are removing standpipes because a lot of wastage has been caused by these stand-pipes. Sir, the removal of standpipes in the Paya Lebar constituency is not done arbitrarily. I am sure all Members are aware that the Water Department of the Public Utilities Board have, in all instances of the removal of stand-pipes, worked closely with Members of Parliament. The procedure adopted before removing a standpipe is this: the Water Department will consult the Urban and Rural Services Committee which, in turn, will consult the Citizens' Consultative Committee of the area. The Member of Parliament is the adviser to the CCC of his constituency. It is only after these two Committees are satisfied that an alternative supply of water is available, or that there is an alternative supply of water, then and only then will the standpipe be cut off.

    In the case of the Member for Paya Lebar, I am sure this procedure was followed. As far as I am aware, I have ascertained from the URSC and the CCC that there has been no complaint from him whatsoever. Therefore, I believe there must be a satisfactory alternative supply of water. Anyway, I am glad to note that the problem which he has brought up has made him realise that water is precious, and it is part of his duty to see that he saves water.

    Coming to the Member for Jurong, let me say that it is neither the policy nor the duty of the Ministry of the Environment to remove trade or industrial refuse. Removal of trade or industrial refuse is part of the manufacturing process. The Government will try its best to remove refuse from trade premises and from houses daily. It is only when there is an increase in absenteeism of the workers, usually during festivals and holidays, when a greater amount of refuse is discarded that there is a pile-up of refuse. This is perhaps also because of the higher standard of living. It is usual to find that there is an increase in absenteeism

Column: 742

during public holidays. And to highlight the problem, the newspapers publish a picture of a refuse heap just before it is removed. I think we are probably one of the few countries in the world where refuse is being removed daily, and it is not our duty to remove industrial refuse or trade waste. If the Member for Jurong said that manufacturers are willing to pay for its removal, I am sure there are many contractors who are willing to remove their refuse for them.

    As for the fire hazard arising from industrial waste, it is largely because the factories have a very irresponsible attitude: they pile up their refuse and leave it there for quite some time. That is where the hazard lies.

    I would like to reassure the Member for Jurong and the House again that the air in Singapore, including Jurong, is quite pure. We take measurements regularly and when factories violate anti-pollution requirements, action is taken against them. A number of offenders have been warned. In fact, two of them have been prosecuted under the Clean Air Act, because their chimneys have been emitting an excessive amount of smoke. A few others were also prosecuted for open burning of trade waste, thus causing a nuisance. An acid works has also been fined for emitting acidic fumes which exceed the minimum allowed.

    I think it is advisable for hon. Members to note that open burning of trade and industrial refuse is now prohibited under the Clean Air Act. This Act was gazetted on the 26th of January this year. I would like to assure the Member for Jurong that the Anti-Pollution Unit will continue to closely watch emission from the various factories, and there will be no let up in their surveillance. We will not hesitate to bring the offending factories to court, as most of them have been given more than adequate time to comply with the requirements of the Clean Air Act.

    As regards pollution in the urban area from motor vehicles, this is being closely watched. The Anti-Pollution

Column: 743

Unit is working closely with the Registry of Vehicles on the measures to be taken to control pollution from this source.

    I am glad also that the Member for Jurong has invited my inspectors to go to Jurong and ticket those people who have been throwing refuse all over the place. I only hope that when summonses arc issued to these offenders, he will not come up to me and ask for the summonses to be waived.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, since we are ahead of guillotine time, I wonder whether you will permit mc to say a few words.

    The Chairman: Yes.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I do not wish to participate in this debate, but I just want to make a point of clarification. I think the Minister had side-tracked his answer to the question of the Member for Paya Lebar. What the Member for Paya Lebar asked was that since the standpipe has been removed, the villagers were not able to get any water. So they asked the PUB to supply them with water. But the PUB said. "You do not have a number to your house, and therefore we cannot supply you with water." So under the circumstances how are these villagers going to get their supply of water?

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the Member for Bras Basah for his support and assistance in clarifying my question to the Minister. The question I raised was not answered at all. The Minister has not answered my point. My question is: is it possible for water supply to he given to unnumbered houses? In other words, is the PUB prepared to supply water to unnumbered houses? I am not complaining against the removal of stand pipes. I am fully behind the Minister in removing the standpipes, because of the wastage caused. But once the standpipes have been cut off, the PUB must give an alternative water supply to the villagers.

Column: 744



    The second question I wish to clarify is this. He has said that the CCC and the Member of Parliament for the area have not complained to the Urban and Rural Services Committee. In fact, the URSC informed us that these stand-pipes would be cut off, and I was advised to tell the villagers to apply for an alternative water supply. I asked them to do so, but their applications were turned down. There was a stand-pipe at Lorong Tai Seng market meant for the hawkers to keep their places clean. We brought this up with the URSC and requested for a standpipe to be installed at Lorong Tai Seng, near the market. It was turned down. We did take action on this. My question is not so much about standpipes. My question is: is the Minister prepared to grant water supply to those people living in unnumbered houses? Yes or no? That is all.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, let me ask him a question: will he pay for the water consumed by these people? Since they have no house numbers, where can I send the bill to? That is the reason why the Water Department does not approve applications from residents of unnumbered houses, because we cannot send the bill to these people. That is the simple reason.

    As regards consultation with the URSC, I think we have had none of these problems from any of the other Members, and we do not disconnect the water supply unless the URSC and the CCC are satisfied that there is an alternative water supply. I presume when the CCC says so, it has the benefit of the advice of the Member of Parliament concerned, and unless they say that there is an alternative supply, or there is available an alternative supply, we do not cut off the water supply. We know how difficult it is for people to be without water. Therefore, if the Member for Paya Lebar has really looked into the problem, he would have raised the matter with the CCC and the URSC. We do not cut off water supply without making sure there is an alternative supply.

Column: 745



3.00 p.m.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I withdraw my amendment, I would like to tell the Minister that in 1972 I made an application for a standpipe to be erected at Lorong Tai Seng market, but this was turned down. The crux of the matter is still this. The Minister says that it is difficult to send the water bills to the unnumbered houses. It is a very simple matter. Even though there are no houses in Singapore we may have to build thousands upon thousands of houses for the people. Assuming that there are no numbers, we can still send the bills to the houses. It is as simple as that.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not number the houses for people.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Sir, the question is not whether you are responsible for giving the house numbers. You can give a special number for the supply of water and electricity. Then with that special number, you will be able to get the bills paid.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, this is the first time I have heard of a "water number". What is a water number? Who gives the water number? And with the water number, can you find the addresses? The answer is that, if you do not have numbers to our houses, you do not get water.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of the Environment is a new Ministry. The consumers' numbers are available. We can ask the URSC.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the answer is a very simple one. If these attap house dwellers at the moment have no house numbers with which to apply to the PUB for water supplies, then the simple thing for them to do is to come to the Ministry of National Development,

Column: 746

Building Control Division, for assistance in applying for house numbers to be given by the Property Tax Division. That is the proper way to solve the problem. If the Member has any special difficulties, he can write to my Ministry for attention.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): I would like to thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development for his answer. My concern is that when these people who live in unnumbered houses write to the department, then they would be considered as dwellers of unauthorised houses and their houses would be pulled down.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon(In Mandarin): This is not a question of the demolition of unauthorised houses. But if the Member has any difficulty we are prepared at any time to give him assistance.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Sir, I am not satisfied with the answer given by the Minister for the Environment. I would like to call for a Division.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0801 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1071.

    Sir, since the implementation of legislation for the control of pollution in Singapore, there has been a remarkable improvement in the environment. However, I wish to point out the dirty and smelly condition of the rubbish collection centres located in different parts of the island. Obviously certain centres do not have enough containers for the collection of rubbish. Consequently, there is a fantastic amount of rubbish spilling on to the road resulting in dirty and smelly roads. One clear example is the rubbish collection centre next to Kandang Kerbau market. Not only does the rubbish spill on to the road but also into the canal next to it. All efforts will be wasted if the hawkers are careless or if there are insufficient bins at the collection centres. It is very unhygienic for health and could result in the breeding of flies. I hope the department concerned would look into it and see that the rubbish is cleared at least twice a day, even on holidays and Sundays, especially in the hawker areas and housing estates.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, we try our best to clear all the refuse. But, as I said, during holidays there is usually an increase in absenteeism and also an increase in rubbish because of the rise in the standard of living. The Member for Anson suggested that we remove the rubbish at least twice a day. 1 have known of instances where we remove the rubbish five times a day and the rubbish still keep piling up. We are trying to solve the problem by mechanisation, and if the Member will help us recruit workers, probably the problem could be more easily solved.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, the Minister for the Environment has asked me to recruit workers. What does he mean by that? He is a responsible Minister. He should recruit the workers. If he cannot get the workers in Singapore, he should import them from other countries under an agreement.

    The Chairman: Do you want to take a vote on that, Mr P. Govindaswamy?

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0801 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1182.

    Sir, we should feel proud that foreigners visiting our country praise Singapore for its cleanliness. The cleanliness of our city is well looked after. But, to my surprise, the rural areas are neglected. During my periodical tour of my constituency, the residents approached me and complained that refuse in the kampungs were not removed, sonic-times for weeks. Sir, I think the other Members of the rural constituencies also face the same problem. I appeal to the Minister to immediately look into this matter with great urgency and to pay more attention to the health of the rural people.

Column: 749



    Sir, I would also like to bring to the attention of the Minister the problem of inconsiderate drivers of Public Health vehicles which carry refuse for dumping at Koh Sek Lim Road. They drive at a pretty fast speed along the narrow roads, thereby spilling the refuse on to the roads and, at the same time, this is quite dangerous to the children in the villages. I hope that the Minister will take immediate action to remedy the situation.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I presume the Member for Changi must be talking about rural areas which are inaccessible either to the vehicles of the Ministry or to hand-carts, because normally where premises are accessible to the Ministry's vehicles, the refuse is collected direct. Where premises are not accessible to the vehicles of the Ministry, the refuse is collected by hand-carts. It is only in places where it is inaccessible either to lorries or to hand-carts that we ask the residents to bring their refuse to the collection centre. I have already mentioned just now that there is a shortage of workers and to remove refuse by hand is labour-intensive. The problem here is to find enough men to do that. However, as I said, we are mechanising, and I hope that with more mechanisation we can make-do with less manual labour.

    With regard to the complaint about inconsiderate driving by drivers of the Ministry's vehicles along Koh Sek Lim Road, it is difficult to take action. We have asked our inspectors and drivers to be considerate and to be careful in what they do. But if the Member for Changi can give me specific instances of inconsiderate driving, resulting in refuse spilling on to the road, action will be taken.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I have been noticing that many drains have been found to be choked and the flow of water is being obstructed, especially with the underground and the monsoon drains. It is therefore necessary to clear these drains as often as possible. Some of them are found to be awfully smelly and filthy, for example, the drain along North Bridge Road opposite the former Raffles Institution.

    Sir, I would also like to know the progress of the construction work at Rochore Canal, which will provide a better drainage system. It looks as if the work has stopped. If so, why is the work left uncompleted?

    Sir, I would also like to voice out that there are many places, especially at construction sites, where stagnant pools of water are found, and these become grounds for mosquito breeding. This may affect the health of our citizens, even for the people living in the Housing Board flats. I wonder what is the Department doing to get rid of this menace.
